text:
Has anyone gotten this error message loading Plots / any ideas how to fix it?
```┌ Info: Precompiling Plots [91a5bcdd-55d7-5caf-9e0b-520d859cae80]
└ @ Base loading.jl:1313
ERROR: LoadError: LoadError: InitError: could not load library "/global/homes/m/marius/.julia/artifacts/e6e5f41352118bbeb44677765ebccab8c151c72a/lib/libssl.so"
/usr/lib64/libcrypto.so.1.1: version `OPENSSL_1_1_1' not found (required by /global/homes/m/marius/.julia/artifacts/e6e5f41352118bbeb44677765ebccab8c151c72a/lib/libssl.so)```

text:
in a fresh Julia session, do
```julia> using Libdl

julia> println.(dllist());
linux-vdso.so.1
/usr/lib/libdl.so.2
/usr/lib/libpthread.so.0
/usr/lib/libc.so.6
[...]```
what do you get?

elements.text: If you empty LD_LIBRARY_PATH when running Julia you should be good to go

text: Yea, most of those are coming from modules that are loaded, trying to remove them one by one to see which. This is the only thing Ive ever seen broken by this and I've been running stuff here forever fwiw

elements.text: Yea, most of those are coming from modules that are loaded, trying to remove them one by one to see which. This is the only thing Ive ever seen broken by this and I've been running stuff here forever fwiw

text: you may have to do some setup for e.g. CUDA.jl though to make sure it uses the system CUDA anyway

elements.text: you may have to do some setup for e.g. CUDA.jl though to make sure it uses the system CUDA anyway

text: also MPI.jl

text: It's probably a bit extreme, but Julia's approach of trying to isolate from the rest of the system has some benefits, like not messing it up (conda, I'm looking at you)

elements.text: It's probably a bit extreme, but Julia's approach of trying to isolate from the rest of the system has some benefits, like not messing it up (conda, I'm looking at you)

text: hm ok perhaps obvious but it was the `/usr/lib64` hiding in `LD_LIBRARY_PATH`

/usr/lib64

text: nice

elements.text: nice

text: just keep in mind, most julia packages that depend on the "big guns" (e.g. MPI, CUDA, ...) ship their own binary package in order not to mess with the rest of the system

elements.text: just keep in mind, most julia packages that depend on the "big guns" (e.g. MPI, CUDA, ...) ship their own binary package in order not to mess with the rest of the system

text: if you want/have to use the system version of those because of specific versions/patches, they have guides on how to set them up so that the system versions are used instead

elements.text: if you want/have to use the system version of those because of specific versions/patches, they have guides on how to set them up so that the system versions are used instead

text: that way you (probably) won't run into weird dynamic linking issues

elements.text: that way you (probably) won't run into weird dynamic linking issues
